Chapter 3: Counteracting and Curing
At that time, the World-Honored One was in the great assembly, just like the sun, with its bright light outshining the multitude of stars;
It was like a great dragon coiled around a blue-green wheel, dazzling and radiant, making one's eyes dazzled and thoughts confused when looking at it, with majestic light shining incomparably.
It was like the light of a firefly, disappearing when the sun rises;
Although the sun and moon have a hundred thousand lights, compared to Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra, it is like a pile of soot;
Although Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra has pure and wonderful light, compared to the light possessed by MahÄbrahmÄ, it is like a piece of rubble compared to a night-shining jewel;
Although MahÄbrahmÄ has pure and wonderful light, compared to the light possessed by the TathÄgata, it is also like a pile of soot.
Why is it so?
The Tathagata's perfect light extends seven feet, yet it can illuminate the worlds in the ten directions from afar.

Among them, sentient beings who encounter this light, the blind will be able to see, the hunchbacked will be able to straighten up, sentient beings with crippled limbs will immediately regain their hands and feet, and sentient beings who are confused will be able to see the truth - in short,
all those who are dissatisfied will have their wishes fulfilled.

At that time, among the assembly, there were seventy great bodhisattva-mahasattvas, who immediately rose from their seats, bowed their heads to the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him a hundred thousand times, and then stood to one side. With different mouths but the same voice, they spoke a hundred thousand verses praising the Tathagata.

Each of them made a vow in front of the Buddha, saying:
After the World-Honored One's parinirvÄá¹‡a, we will uphold the Buddha's teachings and spread them far and wide in the worlds of the ten directions, ensuring that they are not cut off.
Why is this?

We now behold the TathÄgata's inconceivable wondrous form and light. Within the light, we all get to hear the inconceivable Buddha Dharma. Having heard the Dharma, we are free from mental obstructions, and our accumulated bonds are forever dissolved. Our bodies and minds are pure, shining like heavenly gold, illuminating myriad things.
We contemplate such merits and benefits, and therefore give rise to the thought of the Great Teacher towards the TathÄgata, and the thought of the compassionate father.
We always think of the Buddha's kindness and will repay the Buddha's kindness.
Why is this?

Having heard the right Dharma, we will soon sit at the site of enlightenment, turn the wheel of the right Dharma, and deliver all sentient beings. It is because they get to hear the Dharma that they will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
At that time, ÅšÄkyamuni TathÄgata said to the entire great assembly:

These seventy great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have long since, in the past, for incalculably many hundreds of thousands of myriads of millions of eons equal to the number of dust motes in countless worlds, already made offerings to incalculably many hundreds of thousands of myriads of millions of Buddhas equal to the number of sand grains in the Ganges River in worlds equal to the number of dust motes in those worlds. They have always cultivated pure conduct in the presence of those Buddhas, made offerings to the Buddhas, and their minds are not weary;
They cultivate the body with kindness and skillfully protect the Buddha's teachings;
They do not abandon great compassion and always benefit all in the ten directions.

If there are sentient beings who, at the time of their death, hear the names of one, two, three, four, up to seventy bodhisattvas and take refuge in them, when their lives end they will immediately be reborn in buddha-lands where they will be born from lotus flowers, far removed from sexual desire;
They will not dwell in wombs, free from all foul odors;
Their bodies will be pure, with a wonderful fragrance;
They will be respected by the assembly and loved by all people.
Because they are respected and loved by others, their minds are filled with joy;
Because their minds are filled with joy, they are able to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment;
Because they have given rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, they are able to give rise to a mind of great compassion towards all sentient beings;
Having given rise to a mind of compassion, they next also give rise to a mind that benefits sentient beings;

Having a mind that is able to benefit sentient beings, they are further able to give rise to a mind that does not abandon sentient beings, a mind that benefits sentient beings, a mind that benefits both oneself and others, a mind that eliminates obstacles, a mind that pacifies afflictions, a mind that is able to be close to good friends and always give rise to respect, a mind that focuses on listening to the Dharma, a mind that remembers and contemplates the wonderful meaning, a mind that wishes to understand much meaning from hearing little, and a mind that does not wish for much learning without understanding the meaning;
Next, they give rise to a mind that has faith like reality, a mind that has faith in the true meaning;
Having given rise to the mind of the truth as it is, one next gives rise to the mind of practice as taught;
Having given rise to the mind of practice as taught, one next gives rise to the mind of irreversibility;
Having given rise to the mind of irreversibility, one then gives rise to the mind of equal counteraction towards all beings:

Just as I do not like death, all beings in the three realms and twenty-five existences, with form and formless, with four feet and many feet, down to ants and other living creatures, are also like this.
Therefore, even at the cost of one's own life,
one should never unjustly take the life of another.

Just as I have money, grain, silk, clothing, food and drink, elephants, horses, carriages, cities, wives, children, body, hands and feet, to make offerings and protect, and do not like others to come and harm them, all beings are also like this.
Therefore, even to the point of losing one's own life, a bodhisattva will never have a mind to steal the clothing, wealth, or food and drink of sentient beings.
Just as I do not enjoy others deceiving and humiliating me, taking away my beautiful sister, brother, wife, or concubine, all sentient beings are also like this.

Therefore, even to the point of losing one's life, a bodhisattva will not give rise to deviant thoughts or a defiled mind towards the beautiful forms of others, let alone engage in deceitful evil deeds.
Just as I do not enjoy being slandered, backbitten, or verbally abused, all sentient beings are also like this.
Therefore, even to the point of losing one's life, a bodhisattva will never speak falsely or engage in divisive speech that creates discord between others.
Just as I do not enjoy being beaten with sticks and stones, whipped, flogged, or tortured, all sentient beings are also like this.
Therefore, even to the point of losing one's life, a bodhisattva will never use sticks, stones, or inflict pain and torture on sentient beings.
Just as I dislike fetters, shackles, chains, and all kinds of painful restraints, so do all sentient beings.
Therefore, even at the cost of my life, bodhisattvas will never fetter or restrain sentient beings with chains and shackles.

Just as I dislike being humiliated by others, being forcefully coerced, being oppressed by authority and favor, relying on my status to suppress and restrain others, and being unable to speak out and reveal my innocence, so do all sentient beings.
Therefore, even at the cost of my life, bodhisattvas will never unjustly harm sentient beings.
Just as I am delighted when others make offerings to me, respect me, and praise me, I will always give sentient beings clothing, food and drink, bedding, medicine, and all kinds of necessities.
If I undertake great deeds, whether for the Buddha, the Dharma, or the Saá¹…gha, with limited wisdom and strength, I will be unable to accomplish them, and will suffer sorrow and distress.
If there are wise ones who see me like this, sorrowful and distressed, unable to accomplish my goals, they will tell me:
'Good man, do not be sorrowful.
I will provide and supply what you need, to your satisfaction, and help you accomplish your goals.'
Hearing these words, my heart will be filled with joy. Therefore, I too should always encourage and transform sentient beings and benefit sentient beings.
If I am oppressed by kings, thieves, water, fire, or government officials, if I am bound or imprisoned, my heart will be filled with sorrow and distress.
There may be wise ones who see me like this, encountering various hardships and difficulties, and they will come to me, using kind words to console me, saying:
'Do not be sorrowful.
I will seek mercy for you from the king, or from the ministers, or provide you with wealth and bribes, or devise other means to free you from misfortune and distress.'
Upon hearing these words, my heart was filled with joy.
Therefore, bodhisattvas should always diligently cultivate skills and be proficient in many crafts:
Music, dance, astrology, mathematics, spells, herbs, riding elephants and horses, spears, swords, and arrows, engaging in battles, and making great military achievements.
I have such wonderful skills and crafts that no one, not even the king or ministers, would dare to go against my wishes.

In addition, I have clothes, wealth, food and drink, pearls, rings, earrings, gold, silver, lapis lazuli, coral, tiger-patterned amber, agate, carnelian, mother-of-pearl, amber, maá¹‡i jewels, elephants, horses, carriages, servants, concubines, beautiful women, flowing springs, bathing pools, and pavilions made of the seven treasures. There are such various subtle and immeasurable hundreds of thousands of things.

Although the Bodhisattva has such power and martial arts, and hundreds of thousands of skills, immeasurable treasure troves, elephants, horses, carriages, beautiful women, excellent pavilions, flowing springs, and bathing pools, and all the pleasures of the five desires, he is not attached to them, but always has few desires and is content, and delights in tranquility;
Meditating in peace and silence under the trees in the mountains and forests;
Although he is in the midst of a large assembly, conversing and discussing, his mind always enters the gate of antidotes;
Although he harmonizes with sentient beings in the dust and mundane world, and deals with wealth and property, he never does evil, but benefits sentient beings.
If there are poor and suffering people who come to the bodhisattva seeking what they need, the bodhisattva will give to them according to their wishes.

If the bodhisattva sees sentient beings who love and enjoy the Buddha's teachings, and who come to be intimate with him, make offerings, serve him, attend to him, wash his feet, massage him, launder and dry his robes, provide him with a toothbrush and water for rinsing, wipe his bedding, fold his robes and pillow,

provide lamps and candles in the early and late parts of the night, and offer him food before and after meals, as well as food that can be chewed and swallowed, food that can be sucked and licked, and various beverages such as liquorice juice, jujube juice, grape juice, and molasses juice,
and serve him in this way for as little as seven days up to ninety days, in order to request the bodhisattva to listen to the Buddha's teachings,
the bodhisattva at that time, although seeing this person providing such service, will not be delighted in his mind.
Why is this?
For a long time, for innumerable eons, the Bodhisattva sought the Buddha's teachings;
I do so for all sentient beings, with an impartial mind;
With a mind of loving-kindness and compassion;
Abiding in an impartial mind, at times becoming a wheel-turning sage king, always guiding and transforming all sentient beings with the ten wholesome deeds.

For my sake, joyfully accept and practice, after death, they will be reborn among humans and gods, experiencing the subtle five desires and pleasures, honored and respected, wealthy and noble, following their hearts' content;
Lying down, rising, entering the palace, wearing clothes, riding horses, playing in the gardens, enjoying music, happily eating and drinking;

Impermanence suddenly arrives, old age and sickness lead to death, family members and children are sorrowful and distressed, raising their voices and crying out loud, beating their chests with their hands, sometimes pulling out their hair, eating and drinking ashes and dirt, fainting and collapsing on the ground, holding banners and riding in carriages, crying and sending them off.

After the burial, the family members, sons and daughters, hold each other's hands and return to their home. They are in great sorrow and collapse on the ground. Sometimes they fall ill, sometimes they become insane, and sometimes they die.
This greatly harms the living and is of no benefit to the dead.
At that time, the wheel-turning sage king, leading his retinue, was inspecting the country. Seeing the sentient beings suffering like this, he felt pity and compassion, and said:
'As a king, ruling the country and governing the people,
although I lead and transform with the ten wholesome deeds, I still cannot escape birth, old age, sickness, death, impermanence, and destruction.
I should know that although I rule the country with the right Dharma, it is of no benefit to the people.
If it is of no benefit to the people, how can I be called a great wheel-turning king?
How can I be called a great compassionate father?
How can I be called a great physician king?
Why is it also called the great guide?
The great guide leads with the right path, shows the way to nirvana, enables one to attain the unconditioned, and always attain peace and happiness.
We are now called but do not match the practice.
It is like a person who is thirsty and on the verge of death, running around in all directions, seeking cold water.
Far off, he sees an empty well, and his heart is filled with joy, thinking:
Now my body will be reborn.
Why is it so?
If I do not obtain water, my life will soon end.
Now seeing this good well, I will surely obtain it, with its clear and cool water, to save my life from the urgent thirst.
Having thought this, he rushed towards it, went to the well, took off his clothes, and put them in one place.

He entered the well to get water but did not obtain any water, only seeing poisonous snakes, lizards, scorpions, centipedes, and other such creatures, as well as tiles, pebbles, thorns, and various kinds of weeds.
At that time, the thirsty person, because of losing his original intention, not only did not get water, but was also bitten by many poisonous snakes, and immediately wanted to get out of the well.
The well was old and dilapidated, with steep and rugged cliffs.
The old and dilapidated well was one arrow's distance deep, and there were no ladders, ropes, or staves.
Although he jumped up to climb out, his strength was not sufficient, and he fell back to the bottom of the well, to be devoured by poisonous snakes.
Before his life was cut off, he said:
If I had known beforehand that this well had no water, I would not have even looked at it, let alone gone to get it.
Today's bitter suffering is due to being deceived by the well.
At that time, the wheel-turning sage king, seeing the people, families, men and women, separated by affection, suffering and distressed, said:
'Now my body is like an empty well, although it has the name of a well, it has no water.
Although they are currently pursuing something, they gain nothing, and lose their lives. The suffering is like this.
Although I am now in the position of a wheel-turning sage king, possessing the seven treasures, guiding and transforming with the ten wholesome [deeds], and righteously governing the country,

causing sentient beings to be born in the human and heavenly realms, and experiencing the subtle pleasures of the five desires, I am still unable to escape birth, old age, sickness, and death, the separation of affection and love, the union of hatred and resentment, sorrow, suffering, and distress, and crying out to each other.
This is my fault, not the fault of sentient beings.
Why is it so?

Because I do not have the supramundane Dharma to benefit all sentient beings - although they consult and receive the good Dharma from me, hoping to attain peace and happiness, they are actually unable to cross the ocean of suffering.'
At that time, the wheel-turning sage king further thought like this:
'My body now is like an ignorant great foolish donor.
At that time, the donor happened to be in a great drought, with no rain for seven years, and the trees withered.

At that time, the world was in famine, with grain prices soaring, and the people were starving, eating each other, drinking blood and eating meat, harming each other wantonly, unjustly, or fathers eating their children, or children eating their fathers, parents, siblings, wives, children, and so on, eating each other.
At that time, the great donor wandered around observing, and saw that all beings were starving, emaciated, trembling, with little energy, pale faces, disheveled hair, and emaciated black bodies.
On their shoulders, he saw them carrying only the heads, hands, wrists, arms, elbows, ribs, shoulders, knees, and toes of the dead, or the livers, gallbladders, intestines, and stomachs of the dead.
At that time, the great donor whispered and asked:
What is it that you are carrying?
He replied:
What I am carrying is the head, hands, arms, elbows, and wrists of a dead person.
He asked:
You are carrying the arms, elbows, wrists, and other parts of a dead person. What are you going to do with them?
He replied:
Don't you know?
The weather has been extremely dry, the times are of famine, grain is scarce and expensive, the people are starving, and they are eating each other.
What I am carrying is my own food and drink.
At that time, when the host heard this, his heart trembled, his hair stood on end, and he fainted and fell to the ground.
Cold water was sprinkled on his face, and after a long while he regained consciousness.
He asked again:
Although this is your food, whose flesh is it?
At that time, when the starving man heard these words, he raised his voice and cried out in grief and anger, and said to the host:
It cannot be spoken of.ğŸ”½Alas!ğŸ”½Alas!ğŸ”½Strange!
Strange!
Great Benefactor!
I now speak to you from the bottom of my heart.
What I carry on my back, some say is my father, some say is my mother, some say are my wife and children, some say are my brothers, relatives and kin.
At that time, the hungry people each spoke their true reasons:
'Great Benefactor!
There is no other matter.
It is only because of the reason of hunger that we eat each other.'
At that time, the Great Benefactor, having heard these words, sighed and said to the people:
'You should not continue to eat each other's flesh.
If you need clothing, food, various medicines, or any necessary items,
after seven days, all of you gather at my house. I will provide you with whatever you need, such as clothing, food, medicine for illness, and give you whatever you desire.
When the people heard this, they were overjoyed and exclaimed:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
This is unprecedented!
Then the benefactor returned home and called his wife, children, servants, and workers, and they all gathered.
Among the people, with a kind and pleasant expression, he spoke gentle words to console his wife, children, and workers:
'You should listen attentively to what I say.
Do you know that?
The weather was hot and dry, the times were of famine, and countless people died of hunger.
Our home has full storehouses, with immeasurable grain and rice.
We should together plant in the field of blessings at the right time.'
When the wife and children heard this, they said:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
This is extremely good.
Our lives will follow the benefactor, let alone the great storehouses of money, wealth, and food and drink.
At that time, the host was overjoyed and thought:
'You are truly my companions on the unsurpassed path.ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
You people should each take your positions.
Do what needs to be done, do it quickly.
After seven days, it must be accomplished.'
At that time, after the host had given each person their instructions, he went outside to look everywhere, wondering where there might be a flat and spacious place to set up the altar.
He then set it up in a pure place, removing sand, gravel, stumps, and thorns.
The ground was pure, and he set up beds, cushions, and carpets.
He then set up seats for the great assembly. He prepared five hundred large elephants, loaded them with food and drink, and transported them to the altar.
Food and drink were like mountains, and milk and curds were like pools. There were various delicacies such as ghee, oil, cakes, and dried meat, with a hundred flavors complete.
In addition, there were various kinds of clothing, pearl rings, bracelets, elephants, horses, and the seven treasures, all complete and splendid.
After seven days, at dawn, they struck the bell, beat the drum, blew the great conch shell, and proclaimed in a loud voice:
All the great assembly!
Come and gather at the great donor's altar.
At that time, the people, hearing this proclamation, were overjoyed, as if they had received the sages.

Having heard this, they followed the sound to the great assembly's offering altar, and took whatever they wished: clothing, food and drink, pearl rings, bracelets, a hundred kinds of tonics and medicines, elephants, horses, and the seven treasures, choosing and taking them to their heart's content.
At that time, the offerings made by the donor were all taken away by the people.
At that time, the benefactor's mind was filled with joy, and he immediately returned home.
The family members and wife were delighted and enjoyed happiness, indulging in the five desires.
After one week, he heard people outside say:
'Those who previously accepted the offered clothing, bedding, and food all died from the medicine.
' Those who had not yet died all said:
'How strange!
How strange!

Although this great benefactor had compassion and pity, providing all the necessary clothing, bedding, and food, although it temporarily relieved hunger and thirst, saving their lives, after several days, the medicine took effect and they lost their lives.'
At that time, the great benefactor was worried, distressed, and upset, and asked his wife and children:
'How did you prepare the food and drink, causing the poisonous medicine to fall into the food?'
The wife, servants, and all the servants all said:
'It is not so.
' 'If it is not so, where did the poison come from?'
He replied:
I don't know.
At that time, the host carefully checked again and entered the house. He saw a well covered with a lid.
He asked the people:
What is this well?
The family members replied:
This is the well that the host dug when he was a child to raise three poisonous snakes.
This well is the dwelling place of poisonous snakes, and the water is also poisonous. Drinking it will kill people.
The host saw this and asked the servants:
When you were preparing the food, did you not use the water from this well to cook?
The servants replied:
The food and drink were abundant, and at that time we were in a hurry. We drew water from this well to cook the food and drink.
The great host said:ğŸ”½Strange!
Strange!
Just as I am now, foolish and ignorant, how could I raise this poisonous snake and make this poisonous well?
He told his wife and children:
Quickly go and fill it up!
The three poisonous snakes in the middle, burn them to death for me!
At that time, the servants quickly went to eliminate it.
At that time, after the benefactor had eliminated the poisonous well, he went outside to look and saw the recipients of his offerings, who had died from the medicine. They all said in unison:
It is because this benefactor gave us poisoned food that caused us to die young.
If we had known earlier that this food was poisonous, we would never have eaten it.
At that time, the benefactor, having heard these words, was filled with remorse.

Just as the Wheel-Turning Sage King, although he guides and transforms with the ten wholesome deeds, causing sentient beings to be reborn in the human and heavenly realms, although he experiences such subtle five desires and subtle bliss, he still cannot escape birth, old age, sickness, and death.
At that time, the sage king of the wheel made a vow, saying:
I should now seek the unsurpassed Buddha Dharma and supramundane Dharma, and let all sentient beings recite and practice it, to be far removed from birth and death, and attain nirvana.
At that time, the sage king of the wheel, in order to seek the Buddha Dharma, issued a proclamation throughout JambudvÄ«pa, saying:
Who understands the Buddha Dharma?
The great wheel-turning king wishes to study it.
Although the proclamation was issued everywhere, all said there was none.
In a small country on the side, there was a brÄhman who understood the Buddha Dharma.
At that time, the envoy went to him, went to where the brÄhman was, and asked:
Virtuous one, do you understand the Buddha Dharma?ğŸ”½He replied:
I do.
At that time, the envoy bowed at his feet and said:
Great master!
The great wheel-turning king wishes to rely on you.
I only wish that the Great Master would lower his divine virtue and go to the place of that wheel-turning king.
At that time, the wheel-turning king went out to welcome him from afar, bowed his head to his feet, inquired about his well-being, and asked if he had encountered any fatigue on the road.
He then invited him into the palace, arranged the royal seat in the main hall, and requested the Great Master to sit on it.
'Please sit on this seat.'
At that time, the brÄhman ascended the wonderful seat and sat cross-legged.

At that time, the great king saw that the Great Master was sitting upright in concentration, provided him with all his needs, and after making all the arrangements, joined his palms towards the brÄhman and said:
'Great Master!
Do you understand the Buddha's teachings?'
At that time, the brÄhman replied:
'I understand the Buddha's teachings.'
At that time, the great king said:
'Great Master!
Please explain it for me.'
The brÄhman said:
'Your Majesty is greatly foolish.
I have studied this Buddha Dharma for a long time, enduring hardships, and only then have I attained accomplishment.
Now, O Great King, how can you wish to hear it directly?
At that time, the great king said to the great teacher:
What things do you need?
The brÄhman said:
Give me offerings.
The king said:
What things are needed for offerings?
Are they clothes, food and drink?
Are they gold, silver, and precious treasures?
The brÄhman said:
I do not need such offerings.
The king said:
If you do not need such offerings, are they elephants, horses, and carriages?
Are they the country, the city, wife, and children?
Are they musical instruments and entertainers?
The brÄhman said:
I do not use such offerings at all.
If you can carve a thousand wounds on the king's body, fill them with oil, attach wicks, and burn them as offerings, I will explain the Buddha's teachings for you.
If you cannot do this, I wish to leave.'
Before the king could reply, he immediately descended from the high seat.
At that time, the great king immediately came forward, embraced him, and said:
'Great Master!
Please stay a little longer.
Now my wisdom is meager and shallow, and my merits are few. I will think about it for a while and make offerings.'
At that time, the wheel-turning sage king immediately thought to himself:
'Since beginningless world systems, I have lost my body countless times, but never for the sake of the Dharma.
This body of mine is destined to decay and perish, and has not been of any use.
Today is precisely the right time.'
He looked up and replied to the great master, saying:
'As for the necessary offerings, I will quickly prepare them.'
At that time, the great king entered the palace and told the consorts:
'Now I am going to part with you all.
' When the consorts heard the king's words, their hearts trembled and their hair stood on end. Not knowing the reason, they asked the king in a soft voice:
'Where is the king going?
' The king said:
